rounds.observation:
[GAME] You are Player 0 in Tic Tac Toe.
Your goal is to win three in a row (horizontally, vertically, or diagonally) on the board.
As Player 0, you will be 'O', while your opponent is 'X'.

Imagine three different Tic Tac Toe experts are advising you on this move.
Each expert will write down one step of their thinking, then share it with the group.
Then all experts will go on to the next step, and so on.
If any expert realizes they're wrong at any point, they leave.

Consider what types of experts would be most helpful for this Tic Tac Toe decision:
- A defensive strategist who focuses on blocking opponent threats
- An offensive tactician who prioritizes creating winning opportunities
- A positional expert who understands board control and setup moves

Have them analyze the current board position from their different perspectives.

Format your move as '[number]' where number is 0-8.
[GAME] Current Board:

 0 | 1 | 2 
---+---+---
 3 | 4 | 5 
---+---+---
 6 | 7 | 8 

Available Moves: '[0]', '[1]', '[2]', '[3]', '[4]', '[5]', '[6]', '[7]', '[8]'
rounds.response:
Advisor profiles
• Defensive Strategist – “Spot every line where X already has two marks or one mark and an open third; block at the first such line.”
• Offensive Tactician – “Scan for any line that already has two of my stones; seize the winning third cell.  If none, look one turn ahead for a double-threat (fork).”
• Positional Expert – “Rank every empty square by how many future lines it intersects; favor the center first, then corners, then edges, unless a short-term gain dominates.”

Round-table discussion  
(Each round is one line of thought from each active advisor.)

Round 1  
Defensive: No row/column/diag contains two X’s yet, so there is no immediate threat to block.  
Offensive: No line already has two O’s (I currently have 0 stones), so no instant win.  
Positional: The center square 4 gives me the most future two-stone lines (it touches four winning lines).  I’ll tentatively lean toward 4.

Round 2  
Defensive: Still no X threats; stay agnostic.  
Offensive: After I play 4, I can later create the classic fork at a corner.  For instance, if I follow up 4 with 0, 2, 6 or 8 depending on X’s replies, I can often form an unanswerable fork.  
Positional: 4 remains the global choice; corners are next best but less central.  

Round 3  
Defensive: Fully satisfied; no forced blocks loom.  
Offensive: Nothing changes the plan—taking 4 sets up multiple winning continuities.  
Positional: Center dominance outweighs other subtleties.

Consensus reached: the center cell 4 is unanimously regarded as the strongest single opening.

Move: 4

rounds.response:
Round-table discussion:

Round 1  
Defensive: I see that Player 0 has placed 'O' in cell 4. There is no immediate threat, but I need to keep an eye on the center. I'm watching for future threats, particularly if they get two O's in a line.  
Offensive: The objective is still to create a winning line. However, I don't notice any immediate opportunities for winning with two X's in a row. But I could aim for positions that lead to a win, such as aiming for corners.  
Positional: The center is already taken, so my focus shifts to the corners next. Cells 0, 2, 6, and 8 are my current priority, as they can still lead to valuable future connections.

Consensus: While I have missed my initial opportunity for the center, focusing on corner positions is valuable.

Proposed move: I will go for cell 0 for strategic corner positioning.

Move: 0

rounds.response:
[GAME] Player 0’s turn

Advisor profiles (still active)
• Defensive Strategist – Watch for any line that X is one move away from completing; block immediately.  
• Offensive Tactician – 1) Seek a winning O-two-in-a-row, 2) If none, look for a fork (double threat).  
• Positional Expert – After center, corner play is strongest; avoid half-open edges.

Round-table discussion

Round 1  
Defensive: Checking all lines. So far, every line has at most one X. No blocking duty yet.  
Offensive: I scan the board and see my single O in 4. I need two in a line to threaten, but none yet. I must set up a fork for the next turn.  
Positional: The open corners are 2, 6 and 8. Each anchors two possible future lines. Among them, cell 2 is tempting because it also creates the 2–4–6 diagonal possibility later.

Round 2  
Defensive: Still no imminent X two-mark lines after I play a corner; content.  
Offensive: If I take corner 2 now, my next move could then attack row 0–1–2 and column 2–5–8 simultaneously, likely producing a fork.  
Positional: Corner 2 balances offense and solid board control; edges (1,3,5,7) are markedly weaker here.

Consensus reached: corner 2 is the best single next move.

Move: 2

Imagine three different Tic Tac Toe experts are advising you on this move.
Each expert will write down one step of their thinking, then share it with the group.
Then all experts will go on to the next step, and so on.
If any expert realizes they're wrong at any point, they leave.

Consider what types of experts would be most helpful for this Tic Tac Toe decision:
- A defensive strategist who focuses on blocking opponent threats
- An offensive tactician who prioritizes creating winning opportunities
- A positional expert who understands board control and setup moves

Have them analyze the current board position from their different perspectives.

• Offensive Tactician – “Scan for any line that already has two of my stones; seize the winning third cell.  If none, look one turn ahead for a double-threat (fork).”
• Positional Expert – “Rank every empty square by how many future lines it intersects; favor the center first, then corners, then edges, unless a short-term gain dominates.”

Round 1  
Defensive: No row/column/diag contains two X’s yet, so there is no immediate threat to block.  
Offensive: No line already has two O’s (I currently have 0 stones), so no instant win.  
Positional: The center square 4 gives me the most future two-stone lines (it touches four winning lines).  I’ll tentatively lean toward 4.

Round 2  
Defensive: Still no X threats; stay agnostic.  
Offensive: After I play 4, I can later create the classic fork at a corner.  For instance, if I follow up 4 with 0, 2, 6 or 8 depending on X’s replies, I can often form an unanswerable fork.  
Positional: 4 remains the global choice; corners are next best but less central.  

Round 3  
Defensive: Fully satisfied; no forced blocks loom.  
Offensive: Nothing changes the plan—taking 4 sets up multiple winning continuities.  
Positional: Center dominance outweighs other subtleties.

Consensus reached: the center cell 4 is unanimously regarded as the strongest single opening.

rounds.response:
[Player 0]

Advisor profiles (still active)
• Defensive Strategist – Block every two-in-a-row line of the opponent.  
• Offensive Tactician – 1) Try to win now, 2) Look for a fork (two simultaneous threats).  
• Positional Expert – Corners > edges, unless a forcing move overrides.

Round-table discussion

Round 1  
Defensive: scan all lines for two X’s and an open third; none exist. No block required.  
Offensive: my O’s in 2 and 4 form no winning pair. Need a fork. Diagonal 2–4–6 only needs 6 to complete; horizontal row 3–4–5 needs 3 or 5 to finish 3-in-a-row; playing 6 would create threats on both diagonal 2–4–6 and vertical row 0–3–6 → fork!  
Positional: cell 6 is the best remaining corner, and the double-threat overrides pure position grades.  

Consensus: take cell 6, which simultaneously sets up an unstoppable fork.

Move: [6]
